title: Ethereum's Next Frontier is Validator Privacy in the P2P Layer
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1998143303603163575.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019b0872bef0-a5730955-14ca-4e23-b552-47196c98db59-000000/cnRR17n8_JkaCyvukwrD8YheJcxuEJCxe9tdpFb_HgM=435
summary: Ethereum's Next Frontier is Validator Privacy in the P2P Layer (2 minute read) Making validator networking private and fast requires attestation gossip via an OHTTP-style two-hop relay (breaking the IP and validator link), prioritized meshes using a ZK “proof-of-validator” (sybil-resistant without revealing identity), rate-limiting nullifiers to stop spam, and decoy traffic to hide behavioral patterns.

title: Researchers Spot 700% Increase in Hypervisor Ransomware Attacks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.theregister.com%2F2025%2F12%2F09%2Fhypervisor_ransomware_attacks_increasing%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019b089689d2-adcd720d-ccfb-4157-885c-4f24ac73816f-000000/gvtXVtfdYOGVtOGbC_zBnVvUh8NYm4oxsSFY-ugUjjg=435
summary: Researchers Spot 700% Increase in Hypervisor Ransomware Attacks (2 minute read) Security researchers report a 700% increase in ransomware attacks targeting hypervisors like Hyper-V and VMWare ESXi, with groups such as Akira leading the trend. Hypervisors often lack endpoint-style protections and offer attackers a control point over numerous VMs simultaneously. Attacks abuse built‑in tools to encrypt VM storage and misuse management utilities to disable protections.

title: How People Use AI at Work
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdejan.ai%2Fblog%2Freport-ai-workplace%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/PW9sPVISXF4fogzTzeZynChJXZJv3PccyJ8scR8gqHk=435
summary: How People Use AI at Work (12 minute read) Professionals use AI for grunt work and first drafts. It is never trusted without supervision. Artists use AI to handle admin work so they have more time for creative work. Researchers find that the time required to fact-check AI output often negates the efficiency gains. The primary barrier to AI adoption is hallucination.

title: There is no data-generating distribution
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.argmin.net%2Fp%2Fthere-is-no-data-generating-distribution%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/ezwccqtzOcVOEsiz4Cc-7wjcaMEIvDTdtxP-ih_TSq8=435
summary: There is no data-generating distribution (8 minute read) The data-generating distribution is a convenient mnemonic crutch for machine learning engineers. However, it isn't necessary for understanding machine learning. The same methods are used regardless of whether the world is producing randomness. We need to figure out when we actually need statistical models of data.

Various industries, including biotech and logistics, can use it to solve proprietary optimization challenges.

title: Reasoning with Sampling: Your Base Model is Smarter Than You Think

summary: Reasoning with Sampling: Your Base Model is Smarter Than You Think (18 minute read) Reasoning skills unlocked by reinforcement learning may already exist in base models. Harvard researchers propose "power sampling," which biases generation toward tokens with high-likelihood completions rather than tokens with many mediocre completions.

summary: Apache Hudi 1.1 Deep Dive: Optimizing Streaming Ingestion with Apache Flink (5 minute read) Apache Hudi 1.1 delivers major streaming ingestion performance gains for petabyte-scale workloads by optimizing Flink integration, reducing SerDe overhead, and eliminating record-level byte copying. Benchmarks show up to 25% throughput improvements and significant reductions in latency and GC pressure, especially with string-heavy schemas. These enhancements are fully backward-compatible.

title: Apache Spark Optimizations
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 23 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FuwfNEe/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/-IhDNvF6uXJGTf6hf-Vc13Pf7Yp8KA07DZ2IBWlvIOY=435
summary: Apache Spark Optimizations (23 minute read) Flipkart slashed a 35+ hour Spark ETL job on 7TB of data by 36% to 20–22 hours using repartitioning, high parallelism, AQE skew handling, Kryo+Snappy compression, off-heap memory, dynamic allocation, and smart caching/checkpointing. The optimizations eliminated spills, OOMs, stragglers, and excessive shuffle I/O while dramatically improving cluster efficiency.

title: Improving MySQL Cluster Uptime: Making MGR Viable at Scale
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.uber.com%2Fblog%2Fimproving-mysql-cluster-uptime-part2%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/KzjG9OE8I5Ax47O_pegnOUg5k1qn-dl1g8lvLOWQKWU=435
summary: Improving MySQL Cluster Uptime: Making MGR Viable at Scale (8 minute read) Uber replaced manual, error-prone MySQL failovers with MySQL Group Replication using a 3-node single-primary consensus group plus async read replicas, backed by a custom orchestrator for automated onboarding, rebalancing, and recovery. This delivered near-instant automatic failovers, strict consistency, zero split-brain risk, and drastically reduced downtime with only minor performance overhead at massive scale.

title: You Gotta Push If You Wanna Pull
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.morling.dev%2Fblog%2Fyou-gotta-push-if-you-wanna-pull%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/uk653RJAr-u7Pyi87rfbeqqccKFohR9iKbp_wNJKTyM=435
summary: You Gotta Push If You Wanna Pull (5 minute read) Efficient “pull” queries that feel instant require precomputed materialized views that handle performance, joins, and the exact data shape the application needs. These views stay fresh in real time by continuously pushing only incremental changes from the source (via CDC tools like Debezium + Flink, or modern IVM systems like Materialize and pg_ivm), delivering the best of both worlds: zero recomputation cost and immediate results on every pull.

title: Should CSS be Constraints?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 17 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fpavpanchekha.com%2Fblog%2Fwhy-css-bad.html%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b0d276ee8-65d184dd-2edc-4a0d-ae71-40cdb142379f-000000/XDygsUmf_7zHxiJF4kYpu1yWNIno4CpbH8rgp5tMf3k=435
summary: Should CSS be Constraints? (17 minute read) CSS is hard, and the rules can be quite complex. It is currently hard to predict what CSS will result in. One commonly-proposed replacement for CSS is a constraint system. However, with constraint-based systems, it is possible to have more than or less than one layout that satisfies the rules. Predictability suffers again once you have complicated constraints and conflict handling rules.

title: Why AGI Will Not Happen
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 24 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ftimdettmers.com%2F2025%2F12%2F10%2Fwhy-agi-will-not-happen%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b0d276ee8-65d184dd-2edc-4a0d-ae71-40cdb142379f-000000/lvnplPJGuFyNqbEoFlF7Ebs1Y-l5i9SvPIsZ7RkjQVs=435
summary: Why AGI Will Not Happen (24 minute read) The thinking around AGI and superintelligence is fundamentally flawed. A lot of the thinking is created in an echo chamber, particularly in the Bay Area, where the same ideas amplify themselves without critical awareness. This amplification of bad ideas is a big problem in shaping a beneficial future for everyone. Realistic thought should be used to shape a future that is good for everyone.

summary: Cydome Flags Mirai Variant Broadside, Targets Maritime Logistics Through TBK DVR Devices (3 minute read) A Mirai variant named Broadside is actively compromising maritime logistics systems by exploiting a vulnerability in TBK digital video recorder (DVR) devices. Broadside uses a custom C2 protocol, a unique “Magic Header,” and aggressively kills competing malware. Beyond DDoS capabilities, it can harvest system credentials, posing an elevated risk to operational technology environments.

summary: HTTPS certificate industry phasing out less secure domain validation methods (4 minute read) Chrome Root Program and CA/Browser Forum adopted Ballots SC-080, SC-090, and SC-091 to sunset 11 legacy Domain Control Validation methods relying on email, phone, fax, postal mail, and reverse DNS lookups by March 2028, pushing Certificate Authorities toward automated, cryptographically verifiable ACME-based validation to prevent fraudulent certificate issuance.

title: I Reverse Engineered ChatGPT's Memory System
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmanthanguptaa.in%2Fposts%2Fchatgpt_memory%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b0de2e5a4-ecea8ec4-4b82-4da4-8b49-a2b541c02ce3-000000/yVgpwr1YGr-63SzjiZ5SsnWTHL0rEPyI23I3wMuNZVI=435
summary: I Reverse Engineered ChatGPT's Memory System (5 minute read) No vector databases, no RAG over conversation history. The system uses four layers: ephemeral session metadata (device, location, and usage patterns), long-term facts stored via a dedicated tool, lightweight summaries of recent messages, and a sliding window of the current conversation. OpenAI prioritizes speed and token efficiency over detailed historical context.

title: Is It a Bubble?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 58 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.oaktreecapital.com%2Finsights%2Fmemo%2Fis-it-a-bubble%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b0de2e5a4-ecea8ec4-4b82-4da4-8b49-a2b541c02ce3-000000/lQQcLWUyeiFRDMvR7Eb0gkIOPmOH-wVq3Bmo1gTpv_M=435
summary: Is It a Bubble? (58 minute read) No one can definitively say whether we are currently in a bubble or not. No one should go all-in without acknowledging that they face the risk of ruin if things go badly. At the same time, no one should stay all-out and risk missing out on one of the great technological steps forward. A moderate position seems like the best approach. Intelligent investment requires sober, insightful judgment and skillful implementation.

title: Vectorized MAXSCORE over WAND: building faster text search for humans and agents
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 19 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fturbopuffer.com%2Fblog%2Ffts-v2-maxscore%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b0de2e5a4-ecea8ec4-4b82-4da4-8b49-a2b541c02ce3-000000/fm3MBlBGDlrf544idTegyrlxsSPi_aVTBmPJw2mlUrg=435
summary: Vectorized MAXSCORE over WAND: building faster text search for humans and agents (19 minute read) Designing fast search engines is a subtle optimization problem. It takes effort to select the right algorithm and then tune it to get the best out of the CPU. Agents write longer queries than humans, so it is becoming increasingly important for text search to scale well with the number of terms. For text search, this means the cursor has shifted more and more from WAND to MAXSCORE.

They are able to make the process of setting up a developer account quick and easy.

title: An SVG is all you need
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-12, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fjon.recoil.org%2Fblog%2F2025%2F12%2Fan-svg-is-all-you-need.html%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b124d24c9-10fe77b1-bfbe-4cb1-a24a-bf7d6a429171-000000/2Hk4ViEcMpC3diFKTzlzQlKIwVQfc2kKvJXmeq8Nsos=435
summary: An SVG is all you need (4 minute read) SVGs are vector graphics in a simple XML format. They are supported on almost every device and platform. With embeddable scripts to make them interactive, SVGs are way more capable than many people realize. It is entirely feasible to implement an entire data analysis pipeline in an SVG. A completely self-contained SVG file can fetch data from a versioned repository, process that data, and generate visualizations without any server-side magic required.

title: Learning Collatz - The Mother of all Rabbit Holes

summary: Learning Collatz - The Mother of all Rabbit Holes (17 minute read) The Collatz conjecture is one of the most famous unsolved problems in mathematics. It asks whether repeating two simple arithmetic operations will eventually transform every positive integer into 1. This article looks at what happens when a transformer is trained on the unsolved puzzle to study how models fail.

title: How We Made 100M Vector Indexing in 20 Minutes Possible on PostgreSQL
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.vectorchord.ai%2Fhow-we-made-100m-vector-indexing-in-20-minutes-possible-on-postgresql%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b21b19ed5-148e1899-32bf-443f-a7a1-28cc7d23af3d-000000/y_Wm5x1uhkXkwHYQPBfhdJvBIjqodMqh0yksWS6KPRU=435
summary: How We Made 100M Vector Indexing in 20 Minutes Possible on PostgreSQL (13 minute read) VectorChord shows that 100M-scale vector indexing on PostgreSQL is practical without GPUs, reducing build time to ~20 minutes and memory to ~12 GB versus ~40 hours and ~200 GB with pgvector. The gains come from hierarchical K-means with dimensionality reduction and deep Postgres contention and parallelism optimizations, enabling low-cost, billion-scale vector search with minimal recall loss.

title: Why XGBoost and LightGBM Are Secretly Leaking Your Data
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fupdate%2Furn:li:activity:7405691431547195392%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b21b19ed5-148e1899-32bf-443f-a7a1-28cc7d23af3d-000000/J07_VveVBHzTXyc2FCPpItVpVGVQhMqsi8iPBOQaqdQ=435
summary: Why XGBoost and LightGBM Are Secretly Leaking Your Data (and How CatBoost Fixes it) (2 minute read) CatBoost avoids a common but underdiscussed source of leakage in XGBoost and LightGBM by using ordered target statistics for high-cardinality categorical features, preventing models from memorizing rare categories. It also auto-generates categorical feature interactions, reducing manual feature engineering while improving generalization.

title: DBOS: 2025 Year in Review with Mike Stonebraker and Andy Pavlo
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv=RnQKluxWB5Y%26t=7s%26utm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b21b19ed5-148e1899-32bf-443f-a7a1-28cc7d23af3d-000000/ZQj7VsMjK3OhJs09YDgDQEmooSVfEDvb5lPDH1EajHQ=435
summary: DBOS: 2025 Year in Review with Mike Stonebraker and Andy Pavlo (1 hour video) LLMs perform well on public SQL benchmarks but fail on real enterprise warehouses, with accuracy near zero in private tests and only ~30% even with RAG or decomposition. As AI-generated code increasingly touches databases, the stack is shifting toward agentic, ACID-durable systems with holistic autotuning, while Postgres consolidation and native vector support are eroding the standalone vector-database moat.

title: If a Meta AI model can read a brain-wide signal, why wouldn't the brain?

summary: If a Meta AI model can read a brain-wide signal, why wouldn't the brain? (15 minute read) Our brains are able to both detect and produce magnetic fields. This opens up the possibility that the brain may be able to read and write its own field. This article explores the idea and how it could relate to consciousness.

title: Inside the Invitation-Only Stock Market for the Wealthy
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FUYIrHG/1/0100019b21c0d7db-43523543-86cd-455f-937f-2dc5f88c4399-000000/sYCbTDXzE5xPDw2tx5vd09aBPaoZuSdj6lPNci7USr4=435
summary: Inside the Invitation-Only Stock Market for the Wealthy (14 minute read) The ultrawealthy buy shares of the most in-demand companies via invite-only transactions long before the shares are listed on public stock exchanges. This small, privileged group can obtain shares of companies still in their early growth stages, while the rest are left with older, slower-growing names. This dynamic is exacerbating the wealth disparity in the US. It could even become an existential threat to the US economy.

title: Stop writing if statements for your CLI flags
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhackers.pub%2F@hongminhee%2F2025%2Fstop-writing-if-statements-for-your-cli-flags%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019b21e70ded-91f3e769-8632-43eb-9ba5-d573386bf8bc-000000/6fXsk27Hm3622GLddWx1jCcfusvDneLPo4UqtopXUdE=435
summary: Stop writing if statements for your CLI flags (5 minute read) CLI option relationships should be expressed directly in the parser definition rather than enforced with runtime if checks. Encoding these constraints with value-based branching (such as Optique's conditional() pattern) makes the relationships part of the inferred TypeScript types, eliminating separate validation logic and catching errors at compile time.

title: Should You Pitch Journalists From an Agency or Brand Email Address?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.buzzstream.com%2Fblog%2Fagency-vs-brand-email-address%2F%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019b21e8b026-d241c785-f9e4-4304-8fef-0a44bcc9fcbc-000000/IStddIot_xQ2uF7v5WOldquWJEzhDBcpKuFBg-9n8Qw=435
summary: Should You Pitch Journalists From an Agency or Brand Email Address? (5 minute read) Who a pitch is sent from changes how journalists engage. Agency addresses drive higher opens (41.5% vs. 35.7%) because agency-written subject lines are more urgent and emotionally compelling. Brand addresses drive about 60% more replies due to stronger perceived authority. The strongest results come from agencies sending pitches from brand domains, combining higher open rates with higher reply rates.

title: Claude Agent Skills: A First Principles Deep Dive
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fleehanchung.github.io%2Fblogs%2F2025%2F10%2F26%2Fclaude-skills-deep-dive%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b21eb958d-2b38da21-1af5-4b6d-b2b7-cec487b65017-000000/zqA8XKEQMzi25YwUIdNYxm1G8SwLcfgVDd_APQ6BeWA=435
summary: Claude Agent Skills: A First Principles Deep Dive (8 minute read) Claude's Agent Skills system is a prompt-based architecture that extends LLM capabilities through specialized instruction injection rather than traditional function calling or code execution. Skills are prompt templates that modify conversation context and execution permissions. Claude makes skill selection decisions through pure language understanding rather than algorithmic routing.

title: Making complex web apps faster
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-15, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblogs.windows.com%2Fmsedgedev%2F2025%2F12%2F09%2Fmaking-complex-web-apps-faster%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b21eb958d-2b38da21-1af5-4b6d-b2b7-cec487b65017-000000/pCoXPLyebPw1n0eEgrCzRjmiSLJZ6vFExY2o3LCgdQM=435
summary: Making complex web apps faster (6 minute read) Microsoft is proposing a new Delayed Message Timing API to help web developers diagnose and fix performance issues in complex web applications that use multiple windows, iframes, or worker threads. The API addresses three main causes of messaging delays: busy receiving contexts, congested task queues, and serialization/deserialization overhead by providing detailed timing metrics and diagnostic information.
